body.name: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (Dover Thrift Editions: Classic Novels)
body.description: This childhood classic relates a small-town boy's pranks and escapades with timeless humor and wisdom. With its hilarious accounts of boyish pranks and its shrewd assessments of human nature, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer has captivated generations of readers of all ages. In addition to his everyday stunts (searching for buried treasure, trying to impress the adored Becky Thatcher), Tom experiences a dramatic turn of events when he witnesses a murder, runs away, and returns to attend his own funeral and testify in court.

manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Twain created enduring works that have enlightened and amused readers of all ages for generations. Samuel Clemens (1835-1910) left his small town to seek work as a riverboat pilot. As Mark Twain, the Missouri native found his place in the world. This childhood classic relates a small-town boy's pranks and escapades with timeless humor and wisdom. With its hilarious accounts of boyish pranks and its shrewd assessments of human nature, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer has captivated generations of readers of all ages. In addition to his everyday stunts (searching for buried treasure, trying to impress the adored Becky Thatcher), Tom experiences a dramatic turn of events when he witnesses a murder, runs away, and returns to attend his own funeral and testify in court.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great, classic tale of boys' adventure
reviews.reviewText: Twain has an engaging writing style. The dialog between Tom and Huck generally is especially good. A bit of caution is needed when reading aloud in just a few spots to edit out or modify words and descriptions, especially for children under 13. The rich vocabulary and choice of phrasing overall makes for a very satisfying story. Just as much can be learned from the boys indiscretions as their noble behavior, which makes for good family conversations. Highly recommended!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Mark Twain never disappoints with a light hearted, fun and quick read. I am 33 and I still love reading about Tom and Huck.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2014
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars An American Classic
reviews.reviewText: This is an American classic and I think every American should read it! For today's kids, I would suggest getting an audio version to go with it to help with the large amounts of colloquialisms throughout the entire book. It found my kids had difficulty relating and understanding the dialogue because they don't experience this kind of talk, unlike many of us did in our childhood or with our parents/grandparents. Listening to it while reading helped immensely and kept them moving along.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2015
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars but I can see why some have claimed that this is Twain's best novel. The fence whitewashing incident is of course ...
reviews.reviewText: I'm not all the way through the book yet, but I can see why some have claimed that this is Twain's best novel. The fence whitewashing incident is of course famous and justly so. The description of Tom and Becky's relationship, the three boys running away and being thought dead by the townspeople (and attending their own funeral), Tom and Huck witnessing the murder of the doctor and later attending the trial of a man falsely accused of the murder . . . the thoughts of the characters as they undergo these adventures are impeccably described. Furthermore, Twain feels free to interject humorous digressions which, considering he was a humorist par excellence, is a big plus.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2013
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Summer Vacation for Kids of All Ages
reviews.reviewText: No one spins a story like Mark Twain. And this classic has everything: humor, love, mystery, adventure--and Twain's masterful writing. In the introduction, the author writes that the book has been written "for the entertainment of boys and girls," yet he hopes it "will not be shunned by men and women" as his purpose is of "reminding adults of who they once were." My nine and seven year old granddaughters and I are reading the novel together this summer, a delight for all three of us.
